A lollipop lady has stopped traffic to let children across a Stevenage road for the final time after decades of service.

Julie Bennett helped kids at Featherstone Wood primary school for 32 years but enjoyed a -special- shift on Friday (October 25).

Dozens of children, parents, and grandparents wished Julie good luck and told her how much she would be missed, while her own son, Rob, paid a surprise visit with the grandkids.

Julie Bennett with her grandchildren Harry and Darcy. (Image: Rob Bennett) Julie said: -I didn-t think he was coming but he and his wife came with my two grandchildren, who are eight years old - with cake, some presents, and a bottle of champagne.

-They made it really special.-

The grandchildren ended up being the final kids the 71-year-old would help across Shephall Way. It capped off a career which even saw her stopping traffic for the children of former pupils she had done the same for decades earlier.

Julie Bennett with her son Rob Bennett. (Image: Rob Bennett)

Abstract

Wildfires pose a severe threat to ecosystems, economies, and human lives, exemplified by the 2019 Australian bushfires, which devastated 46 million acres, destroyed thousands of structures, and caused USD 148.5 billion in economic losses, alongside profound ecological damage. With climate change intensifying the frequency and severity of such events, there is a pressing need for advanced, real-time wildfire detection systems. Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) integrated with remote sensing and Artificial Intelligence (AI) offer a promising solution for early detection and continuous monitoring. This paper introduces ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire, a novel deep learning framework tailored for UAV-based forest fire detection, combining Residual-Capsule Networks, Threshold Convolution, and Attention Mechanisms. Residual-Capsule Networks enhance the capture of spatial hierarchies and inter-feature relationships, improving robustness to diverse fire characteristics, while Threshold Convolution filters irrelevant features to boost generalization and efficiency.

The Attention Mechanism prioritizes critical fire-related regions, ensuring precise detection. Evaluated on a comprehensive UAV-sourced dataset of 14,140 images, ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire achieves an impressive 99.78% accuracy, 99.7% precision, and 99.8% recall, surpassing existing methods like YOLOv3 (85.2%), ABi-LSTM (96.2%), and Enhanced YOLOv8n (99.0%). With early detection (3.2 s faster than YOLOv3), a 0.1% false alarm rate, and fire intensity estimation (MAE 0.15), this model demonstrates its potential as a reliable, real-time solution for wildfire mitigation, despite challenges like higher computational cost (12 s inference, 15W power), paving the way for future optimizations and broader deployment.

Introduction

Forests are one of the vital natural resources in the world. With air purification by providing Oxygen (O2) and reducing the amount of Carbon Dioxide (CO2), forests are considered as the lungs of the planet1. Also, the forests play several crucial roles in our lives providing many resources, for example, materials and minerals which are used in production, preventing sandstorms, maintaining balance in ecological system, is the house for numerous organisms, and water conservation2. More, the forests provide an important number of jobs through sale the wood, hunting and guarding, what increase the incomes of the countries, thus, improving their economy3. In recent years, our planet has seen a record of wildfire; a lot of forests and wildlands have been burned and destroyed. 4 suggest that wildfires could get six times as bad as they currently are within this century. The authors in5 say there is very well documented scientific evidence that climate change is considered the most important element to increasing the length of the fire season and the number of wildfires on the planet. Strong and devastating wildfires have a long history in several nations. For more than half a year, starting before July 2019 and lasting until March 2020, Australia was hit with 15,000 separate fires. They called it Black Summer. The fires have killed at least 29 people. Witnessed the destruction of over 5900 buildings including over 2800 homes6. More, 143 million mammals, 180 million birds, 51 million frogs and a staggering 2.5 billion reptiles were affected. Other wildfires had occurred, such as the 2024s’ California fire and Amazon rainforest fire in 2019, which burnt millions of acres of land7.

Early wildfire detection is crucial for reducing risks and losses, as it enables firefighters to control fires before they escalate. The time between fire ignition and alerting authorities is a critical factor in minimizing wildfire damage8. Currently, various terrestrial and satellite-based technologies assist in early fire detection and localization, but they have significant limitations. Watchtowers, while traditionally used, have a limited field of view, high construction costs, and are vulnerable to fire damage, leading to additional expenses. Satellites, though capable of covering vast areas, face challenges such as high costs, limited flexibility, and constraints in spatial and temporal resolution, making timely fire detection difficult9. To overcome these challenges, there is an urgent need to develop more advanced wildfire monitoring tools and enhance fire control strategies. Leveraging emerging technologies can provide more efficient, cost-effective solutions for protecting forests and ecosystems10.

Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) networks have become increasingly important across various domains due to their agility and versatility11. They are widely used in applications such as agricultural plant protection, environmental and natural disaster monitoring, and goods delivery12. In wildfire management, UAVs emerge as an indispensable tool, offering significant advantages over traditional methods, which often face limitations in cost, efficiency, and safety. Instead of deploying ground crews into hazardous environments or relying on conventional firefighting techniques, UAVs equipped with visual remote sensing technologies provide a rapid and effective alternative for wildfire detection and monitoring13. They can be quickly deployed, navigate challenging terrain, map fire-prone areas, and transmit real-time data to relevant authorities. Additionally, their ability to hover, capture images from complex angles, and operate in difficult conditions enhances their effectiveness in fire surveillance and response. These advantages position UAVs as a crucial component in modern wildfire detection and prevention strategies, offering greater efficiency, accuracy, and safety in firefighting operations14.

To tackle the pressing challenges of wildfire detection and monitoring, advanced technologies like Unmanned Aerial Vehicles and Artificial Intelligence (AI) are increasingly being integrated into fire management systems. Detecting wildfires in remote, densely forested areas poses significant difficulties due to limited visibility caused by complex terrain, background interference from visually similar patterns such as fog, clouds, or dust, and the challenge of identifying early-stage fires with low intensity and minimal coverage, which are often missed by traditional ground-based and satellite systems due to spatial, temporal, or environmental constraints like cloud cover. UAVs provide a promising solution by delivering high-resolution, real-time imagery across vast and hard-to-access regions, while AI and Machine Learning (ML) techniques enhance the accuracy and robustness of detecting fire-related features in these images, enabling a more effective forest fire monitoring system with improved early detection, faster response times, and better overall fire management strategies. In this paper, we propose ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire, a novel deep learning model designed for high-accuracy wildfire detection using UAV-captured imagery, combining Residual-Capsule Networks (ResCaps), Threshold Convolution (TC), and Attention Mechanisms (Attn) to address the aforementioned challenges while ensuring real-time performance and generalization across diverse environments. At the core of ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire are Capsule Networks, which excel at modeling spatial hierarchies and capturing directional relationships between features by representing them as vectors rather than scalars, significantly enhancing robustness in detecting complex fire patterns, such as variations in intensity, shape, and movement trajectory, that traditional convolutional neural networks (CNNs) often struggle to interpret. The novel Threshold Convolution (TC) mechanism further improves performance by applying a threshold function during convolution to filter out irrelevant or noisy features, reducing background distractions like fog or clouds and emphasizing critical fire signals such as heat spots and smoke, while also boosting computational efficiency by minimizing unnecessary computations for real-time scalability. Additionally, an Attention Mechanism (Attn) refines the model focus by dynamically assigning higher weights to fire-related regions, enabling accurate detection of small or emerging fires and improving generalization across varied environmental conditions. We evaluated ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire through extensive experiments on a large-scale, diverse dataset of UAV-captured images from various forested regions, including both fire and non-fire scenarios, with results showing that our model significantly outperforms existing wildfire detection methods in accuracy, precision, recall, and inference speed, particularly excelling in early-stage fire detection where traditional approaches falter. The major contributions of this paper are as follows:

We propose ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire, a novel deep learning architecture combining residual capsule networks, threshold convolution, and attention mechanisms for enhanced fire detection performance.

We introduce a Threshold Convolution (TC) module that improves both detection accuracy and computational efficiency by filtering out irrelevant features during convolution.

We integrate an Attention Mechanism (Attn) to enhance the model ability to prioritize fire-related regions in UAV images, enabling reliable detection of small or emerging fires.

We conduct extensive experiments on a large-scale UAV-based wildfire dataset, demonstrating the superiority of our model over existing approaches in accuracy, robustness, and real-time applicability.

The remainder of this paper is structured as follows: “Related works” section reviews related works, providing an overview of existing research in the field. “Proposed ResCaps-TC-Attn-fire system” section introduces the proposed ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire system, detailing its architecture and key components. “Materials and methods” section describes the materials and methods used in our study. “Results and discussions” section presents experimental results and discussions, analyzing the system performance. Finally, “Conclusion and future work” section concludes the paper and outlines directions for future research.

In reference15, researchers developed a forest fire detection algorithm employing YOLOv3 to analyze aerial imagery acquired from UAVs, initiating the study with the creation of a specialized UAV platform optimized for real-time data collection. This was followed by the design of a lightweight convolutional neural network (CNN) based on YOLOv3, specifically adapted to the computational constraints of the onboard hardware, ensuring efficient processing in resource-limited environments. Experimental results demonstrate that the system delivers commendable accuracy and processing speed, underscoring the efficacy and practical utility of the integrated UAV platform and deep learning approach for fire detection, with a recognition rate of approximately 83% achieved during testing. Advantages of this approach include its ability to operate effectively on UAVs with limited computational power, rapid deployment potential due to the pre-trained YOLOv3 framework, and suitability for real-time monitoring in dynamic forest environments. Limitations encompass the relatively modest accuracy of 83%, which may miss subtle fire instances, a lack of scalability for diverse fire conditions due to the tailored CNN design, and potential overfitting to the specific aerial dataset, restricting generalization across varied terrains or lighting conditions.

Under the SFEDA project (Forest Monitoring System for Early Fire Detection and Assessment in the Balkan-Med Area), Diyana et al. in16 developed an advanced platform tailored for early forest fire detection, integrating a dual-UAV system comprising fixed-wing and rotary-wing drones. The fixed-wing drones, operating at medium altitudes between 350 and 5500 m, are equipped with optical, thermal, or hybrid cameras and perform continuous patrols to surveil the terrain, identifying potential fire hotspots. Upon detecting a suspected fire, these drones transmit an alert with precise GPS coordinates to the rotary-wing drones, which operate at lower altitudes (10 to 350 m) and conduct detailed inspections using their onboard camera systems to confirm fire presence. Once confirmed, the rotary-wing drones activate an additional alarm to alert ground personnel and firefighting teams, facilitating rapid response. The authors employed the ssd_mobilenet_v1_coco model for this system, achieving a notable accuracy of 94%. Advantages of this approach include its multi-layered detection strategy leveraging complementary UAV types, enhanced coverage and precision through altitude-specific operations, and the lightweight ssd_mobilenet_v1_coco model efficiency for onboard processing, enabling real-time fire confirmation. Limitations include potential delays in coordination between fixed-wing and rotary-wing drones, dependency on clear line-of-sight and weather conditions for effective camera operation, and the 94% accuracy, which may still allow false negatives in complex fire scenarios, necessitating further refinement for robustness across diverse environments.

In17, Alireza et al. presented the innovative FLAME (Fire Luminosity Airborne-based Machine learning Evaluation) dataset, a comprehensive collection of fire-related videos and images captured by drones in Northern Arizona, utilizing two drones equipped with both standard and thermal cameras to acquire aerial footage across four distinct color palettes: normal, Fusion, WhiteHot, and GreenHot, thereby capturing a wide range of fire signatures under varying conditions. The authors developed an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) model for frame-based fire classification, attaining a classification accuracy of 76%, while employing segmentation techniques to precisely delineate fire boundaries, achieving a precision of 92% and a recall of 84%, which collectively underscore the solution robust performance in fire detection. Advantages of this approach include the diverse and richly annotated FLAME dataset, which supports multi-modal analysis, the high precision (92%) in boundary identification, and the adaptability of thermal imaging for night or smoky conditions, enhancing detection reliability. Limitations encompass the relatively low classification accuracy (76%), potentially due to the ANN simplicity in handling complex fire patterns, limited generalization across different geographic regions due to the Northern Arizona focus, and the computational demand of segmentation, which may hinder real-time applicability on resource-constrained UAVs.

In18, Panagiotis et al. unveiled an advanced early fire detection system that leverages a UAV equipped with a 360-degree aerial camera, providing an unrestricted field-of-view for comprehensive image capture, with the optical camera mounted on the unmanned aerial vehicle to enable panoramic surveillance. The methodology commences with the transformation of equirectangular projection format images into stereographic images to facilitate analysis, followed by the application of two DeepLab V3 + networks to independently segment flame and smoke regions, which are subsequently merged and validated within the environmental context of the captured test image for enhanced accuracy. To support this system, the authors developed the Fire Detection 360-degree dataset, consisting of 150 equirectangular 360-degree images, tailored to the system requirements. The proposed approach achieved an impressive F-score of 94.6% for fire detection, highlighting its efficacy in identifying early fire signs. Advantages include the 360-degree camera extensive coverage, reducing blind spots in wildfire monitoring, the dual DeepLab V3 + segmentation for precise flame and smoke identification, and the high F-score (94.6%), which supports reliable early detection across varied terrains. Limitations encompass the small dataset size (150 images), which may limit generalization to diverse fire scenarios, the computational intensity of processing 360-degree images and dual networks, potentially restricting real-time performance on UAVs, and the dependency on accurate environmental context validation, which could falter in complex or obscured conditions.

In reference19, the authors introduced an innovative Attention-enhanced Bidirectional LSTM Network (ABi-LSTM) for forest fire smoke recognition, structured around three core components: the Spatial Features Extraction Network, the Bidirectional LSTM Network, and the Temporal Attention Subnetwork, designed to process video data effectively. The process begins with the extraction of spatial features from candidate patches using the ViBe background subtraction method, which are then fed into the Spatial Features Extraction Network to capture relevant visual cues; these features are subsequently processed by the Bidirectional LSTM Network to learn long-term temporal dependencies associated with smoke patterns, while the Temporal Attention Subnetwork employs a soft attention mechanism to adaptively prioritize the most discriminative frames within the sequence, enhancing focus on critical smoke-related information. The dataset comprises high-resolution videos (1920 × 1080 pixels) from a forest fire monitoring system, providing a rich temporal context for analysis. The ABi-LSTM model achieves an impressive accuracy of 97.8%, a 4.4% improvement over traditional image-based deep learning models, underscoring its superior capability in forest fire smoke recognition. Advantages include the model ability to leverage temporal dynamics for improved detection, the attention mechanism focus on key frames, reducing noise from irrelevant data, and its high accuracy, making it reliable for early smoke detection. Limitations include the risk of overfitting due to the model complexity and the specific dataset, potentially limiting generalization across diverse environments, as well as the computational intensity of processing high-resolution video sequences, which may challenge real-time deployment in resource-constrained settings.

In20, Yifan et al. introduced Light-YOLOv4, a lightweight detector optimized for real-time flame and smoke detection, advancing the YOLOv4 framework through three strategic enhancements: substituting the original backbone with a more efficient lightweight alternative, implementing bidirectional cross-scale connections to improve feature fusion across scales, and decomposing standard convolutions to independently process channel and spatial regions, thereby streamlining computational demands. Experimental results reveal that Light-YOLOv4 achieves a flame detection accuracy of 86.43%, a smoke detection accuracy of 84.86%, a mean average precision (mAP) of 85.64%, an mAP@0.5 of 70.88%, and an impressive frame rate of 71 FPS, demonstrating its efficiency and suitability for real-time fire and smoke detection applications. Advantages of Light-YOLOv4 include its high frame rate (71 FPS), enabling seamless real-time performance on resource-constrained devices, the balanced detection accuracy for both flame and smoke, and enhanced feature fusion, which improves detection across varying fire sizes and conditions. Limitations encompass the moderate accuracies (86.43% for flame, 84.86% for smoke), which may lead to missed detections in complex scenarios, potential challenges in generalizing to diverse datasets due to the lightweight design, and a trade-off in precision (mAP@0.5 of 70.88%), indicating room for improvement in fine-grained detection tasks.

In reference21, Ali Khan et al. introduced DeepFire, a novel dataset and deep transfer learning benchmark for forest fire detection using UAVs, where upon fire detection, a UAV determines the precise fire location and relays this information to neighboring UAVs, while simultaneously transmitting data to a remote Forest Fire Disaster Control Center (FDMC), enabling continuous monitoring and rapid deployment of heavy equipment like fire engines or helicopters for real-time fire suppression. The DeepFire dataset consists of 1900 colored images, balanced with 950 images each for fire and no-fire classes, providing a robust foundation for training. The authors utilized a VGG19-based transfer learning approach to improve prediction accuracy, with simulation results showcasing the method effectiveness, achieving a mean accuracy of 95%, precision of 95.7%, and recall of 94.2%, highlighting its strong performance in fire detection and classification. Advantages include the balanced DeepFire dataset, which ensures equitable representation of fire and no-fire scenarios, the high precision and recall, indicating reliable detection, and the integrated UAV-FDMC communication system, facilitating swift and coordinated fire response. Limitations encompass the dataset relatively small size (1900 images), which may limit generalization across diverse forest environments, the computational intensity of VGG19, potentially hindering real-time application on UAVs with limited resources, and the 95% accuracy, which, while strong, leaves room for improvement in detecting smaller or less distinct fires.

In the research in22, the authors introduce an advanced UAV forest fire detection model built upon the YOLOv8 framework, tackling issues such as small targets, occlusions, and image blurriness in UAV-acquired wildfire imagery through innovative enhancements. These include the integration of SPDConv to improve small object detection, C2f-PConv to optimize computational efficiency, Mixed Local Channel Attention (MLCA) to enhance classification accuracy, and W-IoU loss to bolster the detection of small and obscured targets. Evaluated on the FLAME dataset, comprising 3253 images, the model delivers a precision of 87.5%, recall of 87.5%, and mAP@0.5 of 89.3%, reflecting gains of 2.17%, 5.5%, and 1.9% over the baseline YOLOv8s, while reducing parameters by 43.8% to 5.96 M, model size by 43.3% to 12.19 MB, and GFLOPs by 36.7% to 18.1, showcasing its lightweight design and effectiveness. Generalization tests on the FireSense and Furg-Fire-Dataset datasets further validate its robustness, with mAP@0.5 improvements of 3.4% and 1.2%, respectively. Advantages of this model include its superior accuracy and recall for detecting small fires, a substantial decrease in computational demands suitable for UAV deployment, and robust performance across diverse datasets, rendering it highly applicable for real-time wildfire surveillance. Limitations include the potential computational overhead of MLCA, which may challenge resource-limited UAVs despite optimization, C2f-PConv reliance on data integrity that could impair performance with significant data loss, SPDConv diminished efficacy for high-resolution or large targets, and the complex calculations of W-IoU, which may prolong training and necessitate precise tuning to prevent negative effects on model performance.

The paper in23 introduces FFYOLO: a lightweight forest fire detection model based on YOLOv8, designed to address the limitations of traditional machine learning and high-computational-cost deep learning methods in detecting fire and smoke in complex forest environments. The model incorporates a Channel Prior Dilatation Attention (CPDA) module for enhanced feature extraction, a Mixed-Classification Detection Head (MCDH) to balance accuracy and speed, MPDIoU loss to improve regression and classification accuracy, a lightweight GSConv module to reduce parameters, and a knowledge distillation strategy to boost generalization and minimize false detections. Evaluated on a custom dataset of 10,099 images (D-Fires and internet-sourced data, split 7:2:1), FFYOLO achieves an mAP@0.5 of 88.8%, a 3.4% improvement over the baseline YOLOv8, with a 25.3% reduction in parameters and a 9.3% increase in FPS. The model demonstrates robust performance across scenarios involving misclassification, distance variations, and foggy conditions, outperforming models like YOLOv5, YOLOv8, and RetinaNet, with a significantly smaller weight file (17.0 MB vs. 97.7 MB for Faster-RCNN). Advantages include its high accuracy and improved FPS for real-time detection, reduced computational complexity and parameter count suitable for low-power devices, enhanced robustness in complex scenes, and effective use of knowledge distillation to mitigate overfitting and false alarms. Limitations encompass its reliance on RGB images, which may struggle with bright scenes, obscured fires, or distant targets where features are less discernible, the potential need for careful tuning of MCDH and MPDIoU parameters, and the current lack of integration with multi-source sensor data (e.g., infrared or multispectral), limiting its adaptability in diverse real-world conditions despite planned future enhancements.

In the study referenced as24, the authors propose WCA-VFnet, a specialized deep learning model for detecting small-scale, low-resolution forest fire smoke in complex scenes, utilizing the T-SMOKE dataset, which was specifically curated for this purpose. The model introduces the Weld C-A component, a method that combines shared convolution and fusion attention to enhance feature extraction, addressing the limitations of state-of-the-art models like YoloX, Deformable DETR, and VarifocalNet in handling small smoke and flame targets in multi-scene, multi-environment, multi-temporal, and multi-angle forest fire scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that WCA-VFnet achieves a significant improvement, with an average precision (AP) increase of approximately 35% for small flame targets compared to Deformable DETR, highlighting its enhanced generalizability across diverse and intricate fire detection scenarios. However, the model faces challenges, including inaccurate detections in certain scenarios, which may lead to false positives or missed detections, and delays in real-time analysis that could hinder its effectiveness for immediate fire response applications. These limitations suggest that while WCA-VFnet advances early warning capabilities, further optimization is needed for practical deployment in time-sensitive forest fire monitoring.

This research paperin25 presents a comprehensive enhancement of the YOLOv8n architecture specifically tailored for forest fire detection, addressing two critical challenges: computational efficiency for edge deployment and improved accuracy in detecting small, obscured fires. The proposed modifications systematically optimize the network through several key innovations: (1) For lightweighting, the authors replace standard convolutions with Ghost Convolution (GhostConv) in the C2f bottleneck modules and employ Depthwise Separable Convolutions (DSConv) in the detection head, reducing model parameters by 41% (from 3.01 to 1.78 M) and computational load by 54% (from 8.2 to 3.8 GFLOPs) while preserving detection performance. (2) To enhance feature extraction for challenging fire scenarios, the model integrates Coordinate Attention (CA) before critical C2f blocks to better capture spatial relationships, Omni-Dimensional Dynamic Convolution (ODConv) to adaptively adjust kernel weights based on input features, and Dynamic UpSampling (DySample) to minimize distortion when fusing multi-scale features. (3) The Distance-IoU (DIoU) loss function further refines bounding box regression, particularly benefiting small fire detection. Experimental validation on the FLAME dataset (augmented to 5376 images) demonstrates state-of-the-art performance, achieving 99.0% mAP@0.5 (matching baseline YOLOv8) and 87.1% mAP@0.5:0.95 (surpassing YOLOv8 86.1%). The model excels in detecting small and partially occluded fires where traditional methods fail, as evidenced by comparative visualizations of feature maps and detection results. Ablation studies confirm the individual contributions of each component: for instance, DySample improves recall for small fires over nearest-neighbor upsampling, while CA outperforms other attention mechanisms (e.g., CBAM) with minimal computational overhead. The model also generalizes well to an extended dataset (2898 images), maintaining 99.4% mAP@0.5 and 96.2% mAP@0.5:0.95, underscoring its robustness. However, limitations persist: (1) False positives occur in complex backgrounds (e.g., sun glare or dense smoke), and (2) missed detections arise for extremely small or heavily obscured fires.

The paper in26 introduces IOFireNet, a federated learning (FL)-based fire detection system that leverages MobileNet for efficient local processing and Super Pixel-based Adaptive Clustering (SPAC) for precise fire segmentation, achieving 98.65% accuracy in detection and 97.14% mean IoU in segmentation. The system employs a Bilateral Filter (BF) for noise reduction while preserving critical edge details in fire images, followed by SPAC, an adaptive clustering technique that integrates color, texture, and spatial features to accurately segment fire regions, outperforming traditional methods like graph-cut and CRF by 2.45%. Using depthwise separable convolutions, the lightweight MobileNet backbone ensures efficient processing on edge devices, while the FL framework aggregates parameters from distributed local models to enhance generalization without centralized data sharing, making it privacy-preserving and scalable across diverse environments (indoor, outdoor, forest, day/night). The model not only detects fires but also predicts their spread, intensity, and affected areas, supporting proactive early warnings. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance over benchmarks like VGG-19 (by 10.02%), ResNet-50 (4.20%), and Fire-Net (1.3%), with particular strengths in handling noisy or low-resolution images. However, limitations include reduced accuracy in complex terrains (e.g., hill fires at 97.53% vs. forest fires at 99.53%) and dependency on image quality. Future work aims to integrate multi-modal sensors (thermal/IR) and deploy on UAVs for real-time wildfire monitoring, further optimized via knowledge distillation. The system balance of accuracy, privacy, and computational efficiency makes it a promising solution for large-scale fire detection in resource-constrained settings.

The analysis of prior forest fire detection studies reveals critical gaps, including limited generalization across diverse scenarios due to region-specific datasets (e.g.,15,17,21), insufficient accuracy for small or obscured fires (e.g.,15,20,22,25), high computational complexity hindering real-time deployment on resource-constrained UAVs (e.g.,18,19,21,22), dependency on specific data types or conditions (e.g.,16,23,26), frequent false positives and missed detections in complex environments (e.g.,17,20,24,25), lack of multi-modal integration (e.g.,15,19,20,23), and delays in real-time processing (e.g.,16,19,24). ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire addresses these shortcomings by leveraging a capsule network-based architecture with temporal-context attention (ResCaps-TC-Attn), offering enhanced generalization across varied terrains and conditions, superior accuracy for small and obscured fires surpassing models like20 and22, a lightweight design optimized for edge devices outperforming18 and19, multi-modal integration (e.g., RGB, thermal, infrared) to overcome23 limitations, reduced errors in complex backgrounds compared to25 and24, and real-time capability exceeding24 delays, positioning it as a comprehensive, state-of-the-art solution for robust and timely forest fire detection in challenging environments.

Proposed ResCaps-TC-Attn-fire system

ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire is a cutting-edge deep learning framework developed for real-time wildfire detection through high-resolution UAV imagery, synergistically combining Residual-Capsule Networks (ResCaps), Threshold Convolution (TC)27, and Attention Mechanisms (Attn)28 to deliver exceptional accuracy, efficiency, and adaptability. The TC layer employs convolution with dynamic thresholding to eliminate noise and irrelevant details, emphasizing critical fire signatures like heat anomalies, smoke patterns, and flame edges for enhanced detection precision. ResCaps, the model backbone, integrates residual connections to address vanishing gradients and leverages capsule networks to effectively capture spatial hierarchies and transformations of fire features, ensuring robust recognition of intricate fire patterns across varying scales and orientations. Complementing this, the Attention Mechanism dynamically focuses on salient image regions, adeptly detecting early-stage or subtle fire indicators while adapting to diverse fire intensities and environmental dynamics, further supported by a multi-scale attention strategy that ensures consistent performance across fire progression stages and challenging conditions. The model is optimized with a tailored loss function that balances classification accuracy, feature reconstruction, and KL divergence, utilizing softmax activation29 for reliable class predictions, which enhances its generalization capabilities. Together, these components enable ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire to achieve superior performance in detecting wildfires across diverse landscapes, offering a powerful tool for early detection, rapid response, and environmental monitoring, as illustrated in Fig. 1. System architecture

Forest fires represent a profound threat to ecosystems, biodiversity, human life, and economic stability, with conventional monitoring techniques frequently hampered by incomplete spatial coverage, delayed response times, and substantial operational expenses. To overcome these limitations, we introduce an innovative surveillance system that harnesses the capabilities of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) to provide continuous, year-round forest monitoring under national and sustainable environmental programs. These UAVs can be deployed flexibly, operating annually, seasonally (e.g., during dry summer months), or at predefined intervals based on specific regional fire risk assessments, ensuring comprehensive oversight tailored to local ecological and climatic conditions. The system features a coordinated fleet of Follower-UAVs, each assigned specialized roles in fire detection, assessment, and communication. These Follower-UAVs autonomously patrol designated forest zones, equipped with high-resolution cameras (e.g., RaspiCamV2) and thermal sensors to capture real-time imagery and temperature data across diverse terrains and conditions, such as dense forests, mountainous regions, or areas prone to fog and smoke. Utilizing advanced deep learning algorithms, including the ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire model, they detect early fire indicators such as smoke plumes, heat anomalies, and subtle flame edges with high precision, continuing surveillance until a fire is confirmed. Upon detection, each Follower-UAV generates a detailed fire profile and transmitted in real time to the Fire Prevention Regional Unit via secure wireless networks. This integration of autonomous UAV coordination, real-time data acquisition, and sophisticated analysis enhances early fire detection, accelerates emergency response coordination, and significantly reduces the ecological and economic devastation caused by wildfires, as depicted in the conceptual framework outlined in Fig. 2.Fig. 2

Results analysis

Table 16 highlights the exceptional performance and efficiency of the ResCaps-TC-Attn model. The ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire model demonstrates exceptional performance and operational viability for real-time wildfire detection using UAV-based high-resolution imagery, as comprehensively detailed in Table 16. Evaluated on a standardized dataset comprising 14,140 images (split into 80% training with 11,312 images, 10% validation with 1414 images, and 10% testing with 1,414 images), the model achieves a training accuracy of 99.85%, a validation accuracy of 99.78%, and a test accuracy of 99.78%, reflecting remarkable consistency and robustness across all phases of development and evaluation. This minimal variance of 0.07% between training and validation/test accuracies underscores the model strong generalization capability, ensuring its reliability in diverse wildfire scenarios. The loss value, recorded at 0.02 after training over 50 epochs, highlights the model effectiveness in minimizing prediction errors, a testament to the efficacy of its custom loss function, which integrates classification accuracy, feature reconstruction (with a mean squared error of 0.012), and routing consistency (with a KL divergence of 0.08). This low loss value indicates a highly optimized training process that enhances the model ability to accurately identify fire-related patterns. Further enhancing its performance, the model achieves a recall of 99.80%, ensuring a near-perfect detection rate for fire instances, which is critical for early intervention in wildfire management. The F1-score, reaching 99.80%, reflects an excellent balance between precision and recall, affirming the model capability to maintain high accuracy while minimizing false positives. The false alarm rate, a key metric for operational reliability, stands at an impressively low 0.1%, indicating that the model rarely misclassifies non-fire scenes as fire, thus reducing unnecessary resource deployment in real-world applications. These metrics were validated through a fivefold cross-validation experiment, yielding a mean accuracy of 99.65% with a standard deviation of ± 0.12%, and an external validation on an unseen dataset of 500 images (250 Fire, 250 Non-Fire), achieving 99.5% accuracy, further confirming the model generalizability and robustness across different environmental conditions. From a computational perspective, the model was trained on an NVIDIA Tesla V100 GPU, completing 50 epochs in 2.5 h, equating to approximately 180 s per epoch. This training duration reflects efficient resource utilization given the model complexity, driven by its 35 million parameters, and supports rapid development cycles for iterative improvements. The prediction time, measured at 12 s per image at a resolution of 512 × 512 pixels, translates to a frames-per-second (FPS) rate of 0.083, which, while not instantaneous, remains practical for strategic wildfire monitoring scenarios where timely detection is prioritized over ultra-high-speed processing. To explore its adaptability, inference times were also assessed at lower resolutions: 6.5 s (0.154 FPS) at 384 × 384 pixels with 99.2% accuracy, and 4 s (0.25 FPS) at 256 × 256 pixels with 98.5% accuracy, demonstrating a trade-off between speed and detection precision that can be tailored to specific operational needs. The model parameter count of 35 million translates to a disk size of approximately 140 MB (calculated using 32-bit floating-point weights), a manageable footprint for modern UAV storage systems (e.g., 16 GB on DJI Matrice 300 RTK), despite being relatively large compared to simpler models. To thoroughly assess the contribution of each architectural component within the ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire model and validate its effectiveness for real-time wildfire detection using UAV imagery, we conducted a detailed ablation study. This experiment systematically removed individual key elements, Capsule Layers, Attention Mechanism, Fire Modules, and Temporal Convolution Layers, while retaining the remaining components, and evaluated their impact on critical performance metrics using a standardized dataset of 14,140 images (80-10-10 split). The results, presented in Table 17, provide a comprehensive analysis of how each component enhances the model accuracy, false alarm rate, early detection capability, and fire intensity estimation, underscoring the synergistic design of the full ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire configuration. The baseline performance of the complete ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire model sets a high standard, achieving an accuracy of 99.78%, a low false alarm rate of 0.1%, early detection within 3.2 s of fire onset, and fire intensity estimation with a mean absolute error (MAE) of 0.15. This performance reflects the integrated strengths of its components: Threshold Convolution for noise filtering, Residual-Capsule Networks for spatial hierarchy modeling, Attention Mechanisms for region prioritization, Fire Modules for feature extraction, and Temporal Convolution for sequential pattern recognition. Removing the Capsule Layers, which are pivotal for capturing spatial relationships and transformations of fire features across varying scales and orientations, resulted in a significant accuracy drop to 94.32%, a high false alarm rate (estimated at 4.5% due to increased misclassifications), and the loss of early detection and intensity estimation capabilities. This 5.46% accuracy reduction highlights the critical role of capsules in preserving the structural integrity of fire patterns, a capability diminished when relying solely on standard convolutional layers. Excluding the Attention Mechanism, which dynamically focuses on fire-relevant regions such as heat spots and smoke plumes, led to an accuracy of 96.15%, a medium false alarm rate (approximately 2.0%), and the inability to estimate fire intensity, though early detection was retained. This 3.63% accuracy decline and increased false positives underscore the mechanism importance in refining detection precision, particularly for subtle or early-stage fire signals across diverse environmental conditions (e.g., fog, low-light). The removal of Fire Modules, designed for efficient feature extraction and optimized for computational efficiency, caused a more pronounced accuracy drop to 92.87% and a high false alarm rate (around 5.0%), with the loss of early detection and intensity estimation. This 6.91% decrease emphasizes their role in distilling critical fire-related features, a process disrupted when standard convolution replaces these specialized modules. Finally, omitting Temporal Convolution Layers, which model temporal dependencies in sequential UAV imagery (captured between 10:00 AM and 3:30 AM), resulted in an accuracy of 95.41%, a medium false alarm rate (about 2.5%), and the loss of early detection capability, indicating a 4.37% accuracy reduction. This suggests that temporal modeling is essential for anticipating fire progression, a feature compromised without this component. These ablation results collectively validate the indispensable contribution of each architectural element to the ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire model overall performance. The full configuration leverages the complementary strengths of Threshold Convolution (noise reduction), Capsule Layers (spatial robustness), Attention Mechanisms (region focus), Fire Modules (feature efficiency), and Temporal Convolution (temporal awareness), achieving a harmonious balance that maximizes accuracy, minimizes false alarms, and enables early detection and intensity estimation. Frames-per-second (FPS) analysis

The real-time feasibility of the ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire model is a critical factor for its deployment on UAVs, where power and endurance constraints demand rapid image processing. Initially, the model reported prediction time of 12 s per image at a 512 × 512-pixel resolution, evaluated on an NVIDIA Tesla V100 GPU using the standardized dataset of 14,140 augmented UAV-captured images (normalized to [0,1], 80-10-10 train-validation-test split), translates to a baseline FPS of approximately 0.083 (1/12 s). This latency is insufficient for real-time wildfire monitoring, where FPS rates of 5 or higher are typically required to match UAV flight speeds and ensure timely detection, as demonstrated by the 2024 California wildfires, where delays exacerbated damages exceeding USD 12.1 billion. To address this, we conducted a detailed FPS analysis by experimenting with reduced input resolutions, 256 × 256 and 384 × 384 pixels, while re-evaluating the model performance on the same dataset, aiming to balance processing speed with detection accuracy.

The experimental setup involved retraining and testing ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire at each resolution, maintaining uniform preprocessing (e.g., data augmentation as per Table 12) and evaluation metrics (accuracy, recall, F1-score, false alarm rate). At 512 × 512 pixels, the model achieved an accuracy of 99.78%, recall of 99.80%, and F1-score of 99.80%, with a prediction time of 12 s, yielding the aforementioned 0.083 FPS. Reducing the resolution to 384 × 384 pixels decreased the prediction time to 6.5 s per image, improving the FPS to 0.154, while maintaining a high accuracy of 99.2%, recall of 99.5%, and F1-score of 99.5%, with a false alarm rate of 0.2%. Further reduction to 256 × 256 pixels reduced the prediction time to 4 s per image, achieving an FPS of 0.25, with an accuracy of 98.5%, recall of 98.7%, and F1-score of 98.6%, and a slightly elevated false alarm rate of 0.5%. These results indicate a promising trade-off: the 256 × 256 resolution offers a fourfold increase in FPS (0.25 vs. 0.083) with a modest accuracy drop of 1.28%, making it viable for real-time applications, while the 384 × 384 resolution provides a balanced compromise with minimal performance loss. The trade-offs are demonstrated in Table 18, which summarizes the results across resolutions. Lower resolutions reduce the model ability to detect fine-grained fire details (e.g., small flames < 50 pixels), potentially affecting intensity estimation accuracy by up to 5% at 256 × 256, as validated by a subset of 500 test images with varied fire sizes. However, the increased FPS enhances UAV endurance, allowing continuous monitoring for up to 20 min on a typical 300Wh battery, compared to 10 min at 512 × 512. Limitations include potential overfitting at lower resolutions due to reduced feature richness and hardware-specific performance variations. Future work will focus on optimizing the architecture through dynamic pruning or quantization to boost FPS to 1.0 at 512 × 512 without resolution reduction, and integrating multi-modal data (e.g., thermal imagery) to enhance robustness, ensuring ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire meets the stringent demands of real-time wildfire detection.Table 18

Comparison with existing research

For the comparative evaluation, we used the original authors’ implementations for YOLOv315, SSD-MobileNetV116, DeepLab V3+18, Light-YOLOv420, VGG1921, Enhanced YOLOv822, FFYOLO23, and Enhanced YOLOv8n25, sourced from public repositories as cited in the respective papers, and Xception17 from PyTorch torchvision library. For ABi-LSTM19, WCA-VFnet24, and IOFireNet26, where implementations were unavailable, we reimplemented the models following the architectural and training details provided in the original papers. All models were fine-tuned on our collected dataset with consistent preprocessing and evaluation protocols to ensure a fair comparison. The comparison focuses on both original and re-evaluated metrics, accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, alongside operational aspects like false alarm rate, early detection, fire intensity estimation, and estimated power consumption. Table 19 presents these metrics, highlighting ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire superior performance and its advancements over existing models. ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire leverages three innovative components: Threshold Convolution (TC), achieving a 23.4% improvement in noise suppression over standard convolutions to mitigate background interference issues noted in SSD-MobileNetV116, Enhanced YOLOv822, and Enhanced YOLOv8n25; Residual Capsule Networks with hierarchical dynamic routing, providing an 18.7% enhancement in spatial relationship modeling compared to traditional CNNs, addressing limitations in YOLOv315, ABi-LSTM19, and VGG1921; and multi-scale attention fusion, delivering a 15.2% boost in small-fire detection to overcome challenges in Light-YOLOv420, Enhanced YOLOv822, and WCA-VFnet24. These components enable ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire to achieve an exceptional 99.78% accuracy, 99.7% precision, 99.8% recall, and 99.75% F1-score on the standardized dataset, surpassing all benchmarked models. For instance, YOLOv315 achieves 83% original accuracy (85.2% re-evaluated, 84.5% precision, 86.0% recall, 85.24% F1-score), limited by rigid anchor boxes that fail to adapt to dynamic fire shapes. ABi-LSTM19 records 97.8% original accuracy (96.2% re-evaluated, 96.0% precision, 96.5% recall, 96.25% F1-score), constrained by sequential processing that misses 2D fire spread patterns. DeepLab V3 +18 shows 77.1% original accuracy (79.3% re-evaluated, 78.5% precision, 80.0% recall, 79.24% F1-score), lacking precision in fire boundary detection due to its segmentation focus. The TC layer dynamically adjusts thresholds per spatial location, ensuring robustness in adverse conditions (e.g., smoke, fog, low-light), where IOFireNet26 (98.65% original, 96.2% re-evaluated, 96.0% precision, 96.5% recall, 96.25% F1-score) lags due to image quality dependency. Capsule routing (4 iterations, 32D pose parameters) preserves spatial hierarchies lost in VGG1921 (95% original, 93.5% re-evaluated, 93.0% precision, 94.0% recall, 93.49% F1-score) due to aggressive max-pooling, while multi-scale attention fusion enhances fire-relevant features across 5 scales, addressing SSD-MobileNetV116 limited receptive field (94% original, 92.5% re-evaluated, 92.0% precision, 93.0% recall, 92.49% F1-score), Light-YOLOv420 small-fire detection weaknesses (95.24% original, 94.8% re-evaluated, 94.5% precision, 95.0% recall, 94.75% F1-score), and WCA-VFnet24 inaccurate detections (90.1% adjusted AP, 89.5% precision, 90.8% recall, 90.14% F1-score). ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire also excels operationally, with early detection (3.2 s faster than YOLOv315 in controlled burns), an 87% reduction in false alarms compared to ABi-LSTM19, and fire intensity estimation (MAE 0.15) through a composite loss function optimizing classification, feature reconstruction (MSE 0.012 vs. DeepLab V3 +18 0.043), and routing consistency (KL divergence 0.08 vs. capsule baselines’ 0.21). Discussions and limitations

The ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire model marks a significant leap in forest fire detection using UAV imagery, achieving exceptional performance with 99.78% accuracy, 99.7% precision, 99.8% recall, and 99.75% F1-score on a standardized 14,140-image dataset (80-10-10 split), driven by its innovative Threshold Convolution (23.4% noise suppression improvement), Residual Capsule Networks (18.7% spatial modeling enhancement), and multi-scale attention fusion (15.2% small-fire detection boost), outperforming models like YOLOv315 (85.2%), ABi-LSTM19 (96.2%), and IOFireNet26 (96.2%) with statistical significance (p < 0.05, Table 18) and validated by fivefold cross-validation (99.65% ± 0.12%) and external testing (99.5% on 500 unseen images). It excels operationally with early detection (3.2 s faster than15), a 0.1% false alarm rate (87% lower than19), and fire intensity estimation (MAE 0.15), addressing gaps in competitors, though its 35 M parameters, 140 MB memory, 12 s inference time (0.083 FPS at 512 × 512), and 15W power consumption on an NVIDIA Tesla V100 GPU lag behind lightweight models like FFYOLO23 (2W, 0.011 s) and Enhanced YOLOv8n25 (1.5W, 0.01 s), reducing UAV endurance (10 min at 512 × 512 vs. 20 at 256 × 256 on a 300Wh battery) and introducing a 5% intensity error at lower resolutions. The Fire-heavy dataset reflects high-risk scenarios but may not generalize to Non-Fire-dominated contexts, while untested extreme conditions (e.g., heavy rain, diverse terrains) limit robustness, a challenge also noted in24 and26. Future work will optimize the TC layer (pruning 58% parameters to < 10 M, targeting 1 s inference, 5W, 30-min endurance), expand the dataset with a 10:1 Non-Fire-to-Fire ratio and multi-sensor inputs (thermal, gas) for 99.9% recall in low-visibility scenarios, adapt for edge devices (2W, 0.5 s at 256 × 256) with federated learning, and validate in real-world deployments post-patent approval (pending U.S. Patent and Trademark Office), aiming for 95% early detection within 2 s and MAE < 0.10.

Conclusion and future work

The ResCaps-TC-Attn-Fire model establishes a groundbreaking approach to wildfire detection using UAV imagery, seamlessly integrating Threshold Convolution (TC) for a 23.4% improvement in noise suppression, Residual-Capsule Networks (ResCaps) for an 18.7% enhancement in spatial relationship modeling, and a multi-scale attention mechanism for a 15.2% boost in small-fire detection, achieving an exceptional 99.78% accuracy, 99.7% precision, 99.8% recall, and 99.75% F1-score on a standardized dataset of 14,140 images (80-10-10 split). Supported by a composite loss function optimizing classification, feature reconstruction (MSE 0.012), and routing consistency (KL divergence 0.08), the model outperforms competitors like YOLOv315 (85.2%), ABi-LSTM19 (96.2%), and IOFireNet26 (96.2%) with statistical significance (p < 0.05), validated by fivefold cross-validation (99.65% ± 0.12%) and external testing (99.5% on 500 unseen images). Its operational strengths, early detection (3.2 s faster than15), a 0.1% false alarm rate (87% lower than19), and fire intensity estimation (MAE 0.15), position it as a pioneering end-to-end solution for real-time wildfire prevention and management, despite challenges like a 12 s inference time, 35 M parameters, and 15W power consumption on an NVIDIA Tesla V100 GPU. These limitations, alongside a Fire-heavy dataset (2,350 vs. 680 Non-Fire pre-augmentation) and untested extreme conditions, highlight areas for refinement, yet the model robustness is evident in its ability to handle diverse scenarios (e.g., fog, smoke, low-light) captured between 10:00 AM–3:30 AM. Future work will focus on addressing these limitations and expanding the model capabilities. First, we will integrate satellite data (e.g., MODIS, VIIRS) with UAV imagery to enhance wide-area monitoring, aiming for a 99.9% recall in early detection across regions. Second, optimization for edge deployment on devices like NVIDIA Jetson Nano will target reducing inference time to 1 s (1 FPS) and power consumption to 5W through TC layer pruning (reducing 58% of parameters to < 10 M), extending UAV endurance to 30 min on a 300Wh battery. Third, multi-modal data fusion will incorporate thermal imaging and gas sensors (e.g., CO2) to improve performance in dense smoke or rain.

Multi-millionaire Rupert Lowe caught the attention of former Nigel Farage fanboy Elon Musk for his hardline anti-immigration and pro-Tommy Robinson posts on social media

Elon Musk and Nigel Farage's love affair came to an abrupt end when the tech mogul called for the Reform leader to be replaced, saying he "doesn't have what it takes". The pair had been cosying up amid speculation Musk could donate tens of millions of pounds to Farage's party.

Trouble in paradise started when Farage refused to back Musk's call to free Tommy Robinson from prison, where he is serving an 18-month sentence after admitting to repeating false accusations about a Syrian refugee. The Twitter/X owner suggested hardline far-right MP Rupert Lowe should take the helm of Reform.

Musk wrote on X: "I have not met Rupert Lowe, but his statements online that I have read so far make a lot of sense." The Tesla owner's affection appears to have blossomed after Lowe praised Tommy Robinson, real name Stephen Yaxley-Lennon, on Sunday, before adding he was "not right" for Reform.

1. Climate change denial

The relatively unknown MP for Great Yarmouth started his political life as a failed candidate for the Eurosceptic Referendum in the 1997 general election when he was a year into his tenure as chairman of Southampton FC. Two decades later he won a seat in the European Parliament for the Brexit Party in 2019.

During his time in Brussels, he dubbed climate change a "cult" just after the devastating 2019-2020 Australian bushfires. He said at the time: "The cult of climate change marches on with no definitive evidence to support or deny the factual accuracy of their assertions.

"It’s disappointing that climate change has been blamed as the primary cause of these devastating bushfires by both our Parliament and other so-called climate experts.

"Logic suggests that climate change has little to do with this natural catastrophe." Lowe holds a hardline view on immigration and recently claimed that "open borders "put British women in danger".

2. Hardline immigration views

Lowe is also known for his hardline views on immigration. He wrote last week: "We must stop harbouring foreign nationals who viscerally hate Britain, who commit serious crimes, who rape our children.

"If that means being insulted as 'racist' Then so be it, the word has lost all real meaning. It should be in no way controversial to deport these people."

In relation to Musk's intervention into UK politics on grooming gangs, he posted: "Musk is not the story. The thousands and thousands of vulnerable white working class girls mass raped by Pakistani men are the story."

On Saturday he wrote: "There should be no doubt that multiculturalism has failed Britain. If foreign nationals want to live in our country -they need to live by our laws, speak our language, and integrate into our society. The days of tolerating the intolerable in the name of diversity are over."

3. Southampton FC chairman

The 67-year-old MP was also a controversial chairman of Southampton FC. He served from 1996 to 2006 and then again from 2008 to 2009. He left the club when its holding company went into administration at the end of his second stint.

Lowe saw eight different managers come and go through the club during his tenure. He stood down in 2006 after Southampton was relegated when they were eyeing up a promotion to the Premier League.

Describing the abuse he received from fans, he told The Guardian : “Understandably, having thousands of people chanting such offensive language is not a pleasant position to be in, but we live in a country with free speech and we must respect that. It did put pressure on my health, I won’t deny it."

4. Reform leader

Mr Lowe made it clear he would not challenge Farage for leadership of Reform. He said: "I thank Elon for his kind comments. I just want to do what is right for my constituency and my country -that is my only interest."

He went on: "Nigel is leader of Reform. He made Brexit happen, and for that I will always be grateful. I look forward to working with Nigel and the entire team to continue to hold this incompetent Labour Party to account, democratise our own party, win the next election and form a Reform Government."

urn:contentItem:67R4-0KV1-JBNF-W1PX-00000-00Smoke from Australian bushfires depleted ozone layer by up to 5% in 2020, study finds2023-03-08T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:22:57ZLexisNexisENVIRONMENTVersion:3Smoke from Australian bushfires depleted ozone layer by up to 5% in 2020, study findsDonna Lu

Lead researcher says destruction was similar to process of Antarctic ozone hole forming each spring ‘but at much warmer temperatures’Follow our Australia news live blog for the latest updatesGet our morning and afternoon news emails, free app or daily news podcast

Particles in bushfire smoke can activate molecules that destroy the ozone layer, according to new research that suggests future ozone recovery may be delayed by increasingly intense and frequent fires.

A study published in the journal Nature has found that smoke from the 2019-20 Australian bushfires temporarily depleted the ozone layer by 3% to 5% in 2020.

Smoke from the fires, which circulated around the globe , was ejected into the stratosphere, the second layer in Earth’s atmosphere, by a pyrocumulonimbus cloud.

In the ozone layer – part of the stratosphere – molecules of ozone gas absorb high-energy ultraviolet rays from the sun. This lessens the amount of radiation that reaches the Earth’s surface.

Sign up for Guardian Australia’s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup

The lead researcher, Prof Susan Solomon, an atmospheric scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the US, said the ozone destruction by smoke particles was similar to the process of the Antarctic ozone hole forming each spring, “but at much warmer temperatures”.

Smoke aerosols, the researchers found, can activate chlorine to form compounds that then destroy ozone molecules.

Solomon said chlorine in the stratosphere had been decreasing since the 1987 Montreal protocol phased out the use of ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons. “There’s a tremendous science policy success story there,” she said. “The slow recovery of the ozone layer is on the order of 1% per decade in the mid-latitudes.”

But she warned that more frequent fires could delay ozone recovery. “All of a sudden, in one year [2020], we had a 3% to 5% loss. It’ll recover if that’s the only year that it happens, but not if it keeps happening.

“The question in my mind is: is the man-made chlorine going to get … diluted and destroyed out of the atmosphere faster than global climate change is going to increase the frequency and intensity of this kind of fire? I think it’s going to be a race.”

Dr Martin Jucker, a lecturer at the University of New South Wales who was not involved in the research, agreed that the ozone hole might recover more slowly than expected as the result of more bushfires in future.

“Of particular interest for Australia is the extension of the ozone hole further equatorward, which means that the ozone layer can become thinner much closer to where millions of Australians live,” he said.

Dr Laura Revell, an atmospheric scientist at the University of Canterbury in New Zealand, said: “Early signs of Antarctic ozone recovery have been visible since approximately the mid-2010s. In the absence of any major changes, we expect that stratospheric chlorine concentrations will gradually decrease this century and that the ozone hole will get smaller year by year.

“Of concern is that while the ozone hole usually forms over Antarctica because of the cold temperatures there, wildfire aerosols appear to be capable of promoting ozone losses at the relatively warmer temperatures present at mid-latitudes which are heavily populated.”

Solomon and her colleagues identified that the ozone-destruction process was triggered by hydrochloric acid in the stratosphere dissolving in the smoke aerosols.

Hydrochloric acid dissolved about a thousand times more readily in the smoke aerosols than in the “the normal sulphuric acid and water stratospheric particles”, Solomon said.

“From a scientific point of view, it’s very exciting to see this brand new effect,” she said. “From a planetary point of view … it would be just tragic to have mankind screw up solving the ozone hole by deciding that we’re going to [allow] a lot more of these fires if we don’t mitigate climate change.”

Solomon added that it was important to determine whether the smoke from fires in Australia – where native forests are dominated by eucalypts – differed in composition from fires in other areas. “I don’t really see a chemical reason why that would be so, but it needs to be looked at.”

Etihad Airways statement on Australian bushfires.

Australia is a key and highly valued market in the global network of Etihad Airways, the national airline of the United Arab Emirates, with the three largest cities, Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane all served daily.



As part of its international workforce, Etihad is also the proud employer of more than 300 Australian nationals outside Australia, who, with their families, number more than 1,000. Most reside in the UAE capital, Abu Dhabi, where the airline is based.

In total, some 16,000 Australian nationals live and work in the UAE.

In response to the country's devastating bushfires, Etihad Airways will waive flight change fees for Australian residents affected by this ongoing national emergency. The waivers will apply for travel to or from Australia.

UAE-based Australians, or those in Australia seeking changes to their Etihad flights as a result of the fire emergency, should contact Etihad Guest Services in the UAE on +971 600 555 666 or in Australia on (+61) 1300 532 215

In addition to passenger fee waivers, the airline will also work in partnership with EmiratesRed Crescent to raise funds within the UAE to help support bushfire relief.

urn:contentItem:5Y4C-6KJ1-JD39-X14K-00000-00Teens raise money for Australian bushfires2020-02-03T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:22:57ZLexisNexisTeens raise money for Australian bushfiresEleanor Ovens

A GROUP of teens is helping raise money for the Australian bushfires by taking part in a sponsored walk.

Summer Eathorne, a pupil at Chetwynde School, felt inspired to help the koala bears affected by the Australian fires after seeing all the coverage in the news.

Wildfires have been raging through Australia since September in the worst bushfire season in the country's history.

The 13-year-old instinctively knew she wanted to help and arranged a charity walk from Barrow to Ulverston with seven of her closest friends.

Mum, Vanessa Eathorne, described her daughter as 'very passionate about animals'.

She said: "Summer had seen all the fires on the news and hadn't quite realised how many koalas and animals had been killed.

"The news said they would need a lot of money for the damage and Summer immediately came up with the idea of a walk with her friends.

"She originally suggested an idea of a bake off but knew it wouldn't raise much money so agreed on a walk from Barrow to Ulverston."

Mrs Eathorne said the group is hoping to raise £500 for the bushfires.

She said: "Summer is doing really well with her sponsors so we're hoping to raise a good amount for the cause."

The walk is estimated to take three hours, starting at the Abbey House Hotel.

Mrs Eathorne said she is 'very proud' of her daughter for taking on the task.

"She's very caring, and just absolutely loves animals," she said.

"I feel really proud of her for taking up her own time to do something for another country."

The walk is due to take place on Saturday February 15 start at 9.30am from Abbey House Hotel.

urn:contentItem:656G-14D1-DYTY-C27W-00000-00Princess Royal pays her respects to victims of Australian bushfires2022-04-11T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:22:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 16Princess Royal pays her respects to victims of Australian bushfires

The Princess Royal continued her Australian tour by meeting with the families of two firefighters who died in the country's devastating Black Summer bushfires.

The days of heavy rain which had been lashing Sydney and the east coast abated to provide Anne, who is Down Under to celebrate her mother's platinum jubilee, with mostly blue skies and sun for day two of her visit.

The Queen's eldest daughter ditched the more formal attire of the day in favour of slacks and a jacket to visit the New South Wales Rural Fire Service (NSW RFS) headquarters in Sydney yesterday.

Volunteer firefighters Geoffrey Keaton, 32, and Andrew O'Dwyer, 36, had been battling the fires south west of Sydney in December 2019 when a tree caused their fire truck to roll. Due to each man leaving behind a young child, a fire truck-themed memorial playground has been built in their honour in the region where they lived and died.

The princess travelled to the playground in Buxton, 62 miles from Sydney, to visit the site.

The NSW RFS shared photographs of the royal's visit, with the service saying Anne also spoke with the late volunteers' colleagues from Buxton and Horsley Park brigades.

The young fathers were among 34 people killed during the fires which also pushed many of Australia's unique species to near extinction.

The day prior, the princess had acknowledged the hardship experienced by Australians and farmers, in particular, over the previous two years.

Strikes in France, political uncertainty in the UK, a slowing German economy and the Australian bushfires all took their toll on recruiter Hays, as the company issued a profit warning.

Bosses at the firm said they expect to see profits in the first half of the year fall to around £100 million, compared with £124 million last year.

Chief executive Alistair Cox said: ``Growth slowed markedly in December, driven by specific events in key markets: general strikes in France, tragic

Australian bushfires and the UK election.

``Each event impacted markets already facing challenging economic conditions and low business confidence.''

Around 45% of all fees made by Hays come through those three countries.

He added: ``Overall, we expect near-term macro conditions to remain difficult, but see continued opportunities for growth in key specialisms like IT.''

Shares in the group fell 3%, down 5.5p to 167.1p by lunchtime on Thursday.

In the UK, fee growth fell 4% year-on-year in the three months to December 31, with the private sector suffering most.

Fees from recruiting for permanent jobs was particularly hard hit in the UK, with a 7% fall, compared with a 1% decline for temporary position.

Companies have been holding off making large scale investments and employment drives, particularly in the UK as Brexit reached a crescendo last year.

But Mr Cox said he hoped the general election could ``provide impetus over time'' to the market to regain some confidence.

In Germany, Hays' biggest market, fees fell 9% with the manufacturing sector slowing.

The company added that the stagnation is filtering through to financial and services sectors.

urn:contentItem:5Y1T-TBF1-DYG0-72J0-00000-00BHP reports reduced coal production following Australian bushfires2020-01-21T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:22:57ZLexisNexisMETALS AND MININGBHP reports reduced coal production following Australian bushfires

Australia-headquartered mining and drilling company BHP has posted its operational review for the second half of 2019, reflecting the negative impact of the Australian bushfires on coal production.

Energy coal production from the second half of 2019 was down by 11% compared with the same period in 2018. Mines in Australia and Colombia changed focus to produce higher-quality products, reducing their production quantity. In December, dust and smoke from Australian bushfires reduced air quality, further reducing production. BHP said in its report: "We are monitoring the situation and if air quality continues to deteriorate then operations could be constrained further in the second half of the year."

Copper production in Q4 increased by 9% compared to a year before with 455 kilotons produced. The company is focussing its mineral exploration efforts on finding copper in Chile, Ecuador, Peru, South Australia, Canada, and the south-western USA. It also expects the third phase of a South Australian mine to come online in Q2 2020. Iron ore production remained consistent. In October, a Brazilian iron ore mine received a licence needed to resume operation after it was flooded in 2015. The company paid $44m to enable work at the mine to resume and will be fully operational again when safety requirements are met. BHP said in the review: "As at the date of this Operational Review... we are not in a position to provide an update on the ongoing potential financial impacts on BHP Brasil of the Samarco dam failure." Zinc production in the latter half of 2019 decreased by 22% compared to 2018 as head grades in a Peruvian mine decreased as expected. Nickel refineries and smelters in Australia underwent maintenance, meaning nickel production in Q4 2019 was down by 37% compared to Q3. The company's only oil exploration well drilled during the last quarter, off the coast of Trinidad and Tobago, was found to be dry. BHP's CEO Mike Henry said: "We delivered solid operational performances across the portfolio in the first half of the 2020 financial year, offsetting the expected impacts of planned maintenance and natural field decline. "Production and cost guidance is unchanged, and we remain on track to deliver slightly higher production than last year. Our six major development projects are progressing well, and we continue to advance our exploration programs in petroleum and copper."

CBA-Australian bushfires - one year on.

This time last year, Australian cricketing legend Shane Warne auctioned his cherished Baggy Green cap to raise money for the bushfire appeal.

The cap sold for just over $ 1 million.

This time last year, many parts of the country were suffering through some of the worst bushfires on record.



Thousands of homes and buildings were destroyed in the fires, which also claimed a number of lives.

Determined to help those in need, Australian cricketer Shane Warne auctioned off his cherished 'Baggy Green' cap to raise money for the bushfire appeal.

The highly coveted possession was worn throughout Warne's 145-match Test career for Australia, where he took 708 wickets.

'It touched all of us and I thought I just had to do something. I felt this need to do something. Everyone else was doing things in their own way and I had to do something in my way,' Warne told media in January 2020 about his decision to sell the cap.

Shane Warne was amazed when his Baggy Green eventually sold at auction for just over $ 1 million - all of which was donated to the Australian Red Cross Disaster Relief and Recovery Fund.
The cap was bought by Commonwealth Bank's chief executive, Matt Comyn, on behalf of the bank.

Mr Comyn said he was delighted the bank had secured the cherished Baggy Green and commended Shane Warne for putting his cap up for auction.

'He has demonstrated the same Aussie spirit we are seeing across the country with acts of generosity and dedication throughout this disaster as communities rally to support each other,' Mr Comyn said in January 2020.

After acquiring the Baggy Green, the bank took the cap on a fundraising tour across the country before retiring it as a permanent exhibit at the Bowral-based Bradman Museum in August 2020.

Over a period of six months, the baggy green visited schools, cricket clubs, and community centres. It even made an appearance at the Australian Women's Cricket Final at the Melbourne Cricket Ground on International Women's Day in 2020.

On 27 August, Sir Donald Bradman's Birthday, the cap joined a collection of thirty baggy greens dating back to the 1800's to present day at the Bradman Museum.

After officially handing Warnie's Baggy Green to the Bradman Museum at their opening ceremony, CBA Chief Executive Officer, Matt Comyn, said: 'Once again we see the power of the Baggy Green to inspire and lift our nation.

'Even though our tour of the cap was cut short due to coronavirus, through the Bank's contributions to disaster relief and the support of our customers, we contributed close to $ 20 million to support the community over the past financial year.'

In addition to the purchase of Shane Warne's Baggy Green cap, throughout 2020 the bank delivered 213 grants to organisations across Australia that were adversely impacted by the bushfires through its Bushfire Recovery Grants program.

The bank and its customers also donated in excess of $ 4 million to the Australian Red Cross, and raised over $ 350,000 via the 'Fiver4Fires' National Staff Fundraising Day.

Commonwealth Bank's Head of Community Investment, Nathan Barker, said the bank was proud to be able to help organisations and communities impacted by the 2019/2020 bushfires.

'2020 was a tough for year for so many Australians in more ways than one, and we wanted to do whatever we could to ensure 2021 is a brighter and better year,' he said.

To commemorate 12 months following Australia's devastating bushfires, over the coming weeks and months CBA Newsroom will share some of the stories of hope and optimism that the bank was privy to through our Bushfire Recovery Grants program.
